attributes.title: Stock Take
attributes.description:
·       A physical stock count was performed on January 31, 2024, to verify the accuracy of the inventory records by comparing the physical stock levels with those recorded in the SAP system. Additionally, the count helped assess the effectiveness of the internal controls used to manage inventory.

·       The physical stock count revealed the following discrepancies:

Ø  Bread stock showed a shortfall  of -35 Loaves,

Ø  Packing material had  a surplus of +1,168 pieces,

Ø  White flour had a deficit of -8.5 kg,

Ø  Yeast showed a deficit of 0.2 sachets,

Ø  Wheat bran had a surplus of +6.5kg,

Ø  Brown flour showed a surplus of +0.2,

Ø  Utto experienced a variance of -1.3 units.

The table below illustrates the findings:
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should reinforce inventory control measures to address the observed variances and improve accuracy in stock management
attributes.effect: The variations found in multiple items (both surpluses and deficits) highlight that internal controls may not be fully effective in ensuring accurate stock levels. Regular monitoring of inventory movements, coupled with more stringent control measures is necessary moving forward to reduce the discrepancies to minimal low levels.

value: Although we are aiming at strengthening stock controls, we will also be closely monitoring all items and varieties, paying careful attention to the Bill of Materials (BOM) that has already been established.
The manager is advised to closely monitor the daily stock take to minimize variations.

·       In the prior Audit, the following variances were noted:

ü  Bread stock had a surplus of 91 loaves,

ü  Utto had a variance of 1.92ltrs,

Packing material had a surplus of 3,523 pieces.

attributes.title: Bread Weight Check
attributes.description:
·       On January 1, 2025, we performed spot checks on the weight of packed bread ready for dispatch to ensure that it meets the required weight standards before being sent to the market.

·       From the analysis of bread weight, cases of underweight, overweight were noted as illustrated in the table below.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Given the issues with faulty weighing machines impacting weight compliance, it is crucial to prioritize follow up to ensure replacement or repair and/or calibration is done.

While the branch's controls for weight compliance across many brands are effective, strict adherence to established weight standards for bread production is essential to maintain consistency in product quality and prevent discrepancies in weights.
attributes.effect:
·       The violation of weights and measures regulations through the supply of underweight bread to the market exposes the company to regulatory and legal risks. This non-compliance may result in the imposition of penalties and other legal consequences.

Underweight bread also can affect brand reputation and can led to loss of customers.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Increase the frequency of spot checks on bread weights.

Ensure all varieties, including miniloaf, are given equal attention to avoid discrepancies.

Enforce strict adherence to FIFO (First In, First Out) to prevent environmental conditions from affecting weight compliance.

Conduct an urgent assessment of all weighing machines and repair or replace faulty equipment.

value:
·       We are emphasizing the importance of not overlooking any variety and ensuring the FIFO model is consistently followed, with ongoing supervision.

It is also recommended that the miniloaf be placed in areas where it is not exposed to conditions that could cause weight loss, preventing it from overcooling.

·       We are implementing strict controls to ensure compliance with bread weight standards, such as closely monitoring the miniloaf to prevent it from being overlooked during packing.

·       Spot checks will be conducted to track overweight and ensure consistent yield.

Additionally, we will closely review records to maintain accuracy.

·       In the prior audit, it was noted that, Underweights in packed breads were as follows;

ü  400g were 8%

ü  600g were 23%

ü  800g were 11%

1.5kg were 11%

attributes.title: Bread Damages Check
attributes.description:
·       We reviewed the damages for the period from December 9, 2024, to January 8, 2025, to assess whether there were any instances of damages exceeding the established standard limits of 0.2% of total production for production-related damages and 0.5% of total sales for market-related damages.

·       From our analysis the production damages were 0.33% of the total production and had a cost implication of Kshs.37,181.47, market damages were 0.78% of the total sales with a cost implication of Kshs 91,562.13 as illustrated in the summary below:

·       The findings were as detailed below:
attributes.effect:
·       Both production and market damages exceeded the established standard limits, indicating a failure to maintain damage levels within acceptable thresholds, potentially affecting the overall cost-efficiency and profitability.

The increased damages indicate potential inefficiencies in the production and sales processes, which may be caused by frequent breakdowns of production machines. This leads to the transfer of bread from other branches, which may not meet the required quality standards.

value:
·       During that period, we experienced issues with key machinery breakdowns, which took a considerable amount of time to repair.

Machine breakdowns led to borrowing bread from other branches, which contributed to the trend of market damages, as we had no control over the product quality reaching the market.

·       We experienced frequent machinery breakdowns, even after repairs, which disrupted the process and led to damages exceeding the established limit, as noted.

We will implement controls to verify the quality of bread sourced from other branches, ensuring that only high-quality products are sent to the market.
During the prior audit it was noted it was found that production bread damages were averaging at 0.22% of the production and market damages stood at 0.64% of the sales.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the mixing charts and summaries was conducted over a 31-day period, from December 9, 2024, to January 8, 2025, to evaluate whether raw material usage aligned with the established BOM and if production standards were met. The goal of this review was to examine both shift-wise and summarized mixing chart documents, with a particular focus on the branch's Utto oil consumption, average yield and instances of remixes, as outlined below.

·       Below are summary of the findings:

ü  Utto consumption stood at 100%.

ü  Average yield was 190.38 loaves per bag.

ü  Average production was 91.44 bags per day representing 81.28% of the set target of 112.5 bags.

ü  The remixes for the reviewed period was 2,129.

The table below shows a summarised findings of the mixing chart analysis.

 

 

 

·    The branch experienced frequent production machine breakdowns, even shortly after repairs. While tickets were raised promptly, the response time from KAF was notably slow, especially during nights and weekends
attributes.recommendation: It is recommended that branch management address the equipment maintenance and repair issues, especially with the ovens, by follow up with KAF to ensure consistent production and minimize disruptions.
attributes.effect: Underachievement of production targets indicates inefficiencies in the production process that could impact overall output and lead to potential delays in meeting market demand.

value: Frequent machine breakdowns hindered the achievement of production targets; however, we continue to follow up to ensure that the targets are met

·       The achievement of production targets was impacted by frequent machine breakdowns, which were communicated promptly.

·       However, we need an experienced technician assigned to this branch to ensure timely repairs when breakdowns occur.

We are committed to working towards achieving the set production targets.

·       In the prior audit, it was noted that;

ü  Average yield was at 190.43 loaves per bag

Utto consumption was at 100%

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       Production efficiency was assessed over a 31day period, from December 9, 2024 to January 8, 2025 with the goal of determining whether the hired production workers were meeting the set efficiency target of 4.50 bags.

·       It was noted that the production efficiency was 4.37 bags per production worker, which was slightly below the set efficiency level.

A summary of the analysis is shown below;

Implications:

The production target efficiency was slightly below the set goal, resulting in an additional cost of Kshs 19,558.8 indicating that there is potential for improvement to reach the target of 4.5 bags per production worker.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The controls are functioning effectively; however, branch management is advised to ensure they are consistently in place and to focus on improving the process to guarantee the achievement of production targets for each worker.

value:
·       The target production efficiency for the uniform oven is 4.5, although we do not have a uniform oven.

The controls in place are effective, and efforts are being made to achieve the targets, though machine breakdowns contribute to not meeting them.
We are working on improving production efficiency to ensure the achievement of targets.

·       In the prior audit;

Production efficiency was 4.31 Bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       The optimization of human resources allocated to the packing area was analysed by calculating packing efficiency over a 31day period, from December 9, 2024 to January 8, 2025 to assess whether the company’s standard of 97 crates per slicer was being met.

·       The findings revealed that the average slicing efficiency for the period was 94.67 crates per slicer.

·       The table below illustrates the findings;-

Implications:

·       The shortfall in packing efficiency suggests that resources, particularly human resources, may not have been utilized to their full potential.

There were also overstaffing which contributed to a cost implication of Kshs 8,208.
